fr: stocker des fichiers dans un bucket
basculer sur le serveur de secours
en: fail over to the standby server
fail back to the primary server

def: A copy of data stored separately to enable recovery after loss or corruption.
A network security system that monitors and controls traffic based on predefined rules.
A computer that provides services or resources to other computers over a network.
A device that forwards data packets between networks.
A device that connects devices within the same network and forwards frames.
A formal set of rules that define how data is transmitted and received.
The process of encoding information so that only authorized parties can access it.
The process of verifying the identity of a user or system.
A unique numerical label assigned to a device connected to a network.
A human-readable name that maps to an IP address.
Software that manages hardware resources and provides services for applications.
A system that organizes, stores, and retrieves structured information.
A component that distributes incoming traffic across multiple servers.
Design that minimizes downtime through redundancy and failover.
To increase resources (CPU/RAM/instances) on a system to handle greater load.
To revert a system or deployment to a previous working state.
To permanently retire a system or service from production.
An unplanned interruption or reduction in the quality of an IT service.
Records produced by applications or systems describing events or errors.
The practice of observing systems and metrics to detect issues.
An interface that allows software components to communicate using defined requests and responses.
A small, independently deployable service that owns a specific business capability.
A lightweight, isolated runtime environment for applications and their dependencies.
An orchestration system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containers.
A software emulation of a physical computer that runs an operating system.
On-demand delivery of computing services over the internet with pay-as-you-go pricing.
A physically separate data-center location within a cloud region.
A geographic area containing multiple availability zones.
A distributed network of servers that delivers content from locations closer to users.
The time it takes for data to travel from source to destination.
The amount of data processed or transferred per unit of time.
The maximum data transfer capacity of a network link.
A Service Level Agreement that defines promised service performance and penalties.
A Service Level Objective that expresses the target level of reliability or performance.
A fast storage layer that holds frequently accessed data to speed up retrieval.
A component that stores messages so they can be processed asynchronously.
A messaging pattern where publishers send events to topics and subscribers receive them.
A technique that restricts the number of requests a client can make in a given time.
The Domain Name System that translates human-readable names into IP addresses.
The Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol that automatically assigns IP configuration to devices.
A Virtual Private Network that creates an encrypted tunnel over an untrusted network.
Multi-Factor Authentication requiring two or more verification factors to sign in.
Single Sign-On allowing a user to access multiple applications with one login.
A security model that assumes no implicit trust and verifies every access request.
Identity and Access Management: processes and tools to manage identities and permissions.
Role-Based Access Control where permissions are granted to roles rather than individuals.
The practice of securely storing and rotating credentials, keys, and tokens.
A release strategy that switches traffic between two identical environments.
A strategy that exposes a small subset of users to a new version to reduce risk.
An automated pipeline for Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery/Deployment.
